body: Started to work on the Java migration. Making good progress.

OMG. What could happen while I've been sleeping. The migration looks like mine, so I won't finish the remaining ~200 lines of that.

```bash
$ wget https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/com/dukescript/nbjavac/nb-javac/jdk-17+35/nb-javac-jdk-17+35-sources.jar
$ unzip nb-javac-jdk-17+35-sources.jar
$ JAVA_HOME=~/bin/jdk-17/ ant -f ./make/langtools/netbeans/nb-javac clean jar
$ $ ls make/langtools/netbeans/nb-javac/dist/
nb-javac-jdk-17+35-api.jar  nb-javac-jdk-17+35-impl.jar
```
I'd say: It builds! One just has to use JDK17. Readme updated in https://github.com/JaroslavTulach/nb-javac/commit/9dfc98261ae8dbce33fc5cf958e4054d64718fec

These changes will be part of subsequent releases of automatically generated nb-javac. For purposes of this PR (which doesn't update to new version of JARs at all), we can live with current JARs. I expect an update will be needed before January release of NetBeans anyway as additional issues accumulate.

> Travis is happy - could you please squash this into a single commit?

sure, squashed

> `org.netbeans.libs.javacimpl` module is being removed by this PR. Clean build recommended.

Yes, *I* know how to fix the broken installation, but what I don't understand is: Why do we break it in the first place? From the description of 82662d3 is the commit, that breaks the case. Why not live on with the unmerged module?
Thank you.

> Why not live on with the unmerged module?

I have never understood the separation between the Javac API and Javac impl. They have the closest [proximity](http://wiki.apidesign.org/wiki/Proximity) possible. Different versions are unlikely to work with each other. [NetBeans Runtime Container](http://wiki.apidesign.org/wiki/NetBeans_Runtime_Container) has other ways to hide the implementation - not expose its packages to public. 

With two modules we are facing classloading issues: when the `javax/tools/ToolProvider` from Javac API is using `ServiceLoader`, it may not find the right implementation, but rather an implementation from the JDK. That doesn't happen with a single module.

We have problems with enabling/disabling. Both the API and the Impl need to be enabled & disabled at once (ability to disable the `nbjavac` requested by Michael). While it might be possible to use autoload/eager properly, putting both JARs into the same module solves the problem without any intricate hassle.

I would recommend to consider moving
```
OpenIDE-Module-Recommends: org.netbeans.libs.nbjavac
```
from `java.kit` to `java.source.base` - so that in any situation that depend on java src model nbjavac gets activated, if possible. The LSP server AFAIK does not bundle entire java.kit, still it could benefit from nbjavac enabled.

> I would recommend to consider moving `OpenIDE-Module-Recommends: org.netbeans.libs.nbjavac` from `java.kit` to `java.source.base` - so that in any situation that depend on java src model nbjavac gets activated, if possible. The LSP server AFAIK does not bundle entire java.kit, still it could benefit from nbjavac enabled.

(In my own NetBeans Platform app, I noticed that simply setting "--laf com.formdev.flatlaf.FlatLightLaf" in app.conf did not work, due to the FlatLAF module not being loaded early enough in the startup sequence.)

Obsolete since #3323 has been integrated.

Now there's a new JetBrains IDE called Fleet, and even JetBrains now puts the tab selection highlight at the top rather than at the bottom of the tab:

![Fleet](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/886243/143899239-4bca31fb-990a-4e86-b624-f3b3b1c75904.png)

I think the bottom of the tab really needs to have the same color as the background of the pane below; that's what makes it look like a tab. The blue tab selection highlight looks good, but needs to be on the outer edge of the tab to avoid disrupting the background color continuity. See e.g. Fleet, Unity, Excel, PowerBI, and Thunderbird.

(This comment is about window system tabs specifically. Per my previous comment, I still think it's a good idea to use the simplified FlatLAF tabs elsewhere in the UI, like in the Output pane, where having two different styles avoids the clutter of nested tab components. It's like having two different heading levels in a document.)

Agreed!  My objection to your initial proposal was mostly based on the addition of borders and a gradient - ie. no longer being flat. Using a revised flat background colour, and moving the highlight (not always blue!) above, makes sense.

How will this work for colored tabs and multi tabs? Just to leave this information here. Also we have this option to show the file path below the tabs and also the editor toolbar: I really like when the tab is part of the editor that looks very good, I just wanted to get the attention for the other cases that we already have.

I hadn't heard your objection about gradients before! There's a reason for the gradients that I hadn't explained before.

The problem is to make the relationship between the tab and the editor visually clear, as well as clearly showing which tab is selected. Having mocked up various different styles, I came to a couple of conflusions:
1) The background color of the bottom of the tab card needs to connect with the background color of the pane below (as mentioned before). And...
2) The background color of the selected tab needs to be brighter than the unselected tabs.

The problem is that the editor toolbar is the same brightness as the unselected tab background color. Changing the background colors of the editor toolbar or the draggable spaces between the TopComponents did not look good, in part because there are three levels of surfaces involved (application toolbar and unselected tab area, the editor toolbar, and the editor). The solution was to put a gradient on the selected tab, so the top could be made brighter and the tab would stand out.

As for the borders, these are actually _more_ consistent with the rest of the window than the previous style, because there are already borders around each TopComponent. If there are borders around each TopComponent, having them continue around the tab card looks good:

![Continues](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/886243/143907223-b2e942e0-4ef7-4b9c-97e3-46a2f9f72669.png)

If we really wanted to get rid of borders, we'd need to remove them from the space between the TopComponents as well. (See the Unity screenshot for an example of that. Visual Studio 2022, on the other hand, keeps the borders.)
@junichi11 Thank you.

@Chris2011 With any one of those options activated, you would see the old editor tab style for now. I think they actually use a different tab component altogether. To my knowledge Connector/J is distributed under GPLv2-only, so we can't ship it. I tested with my local version and when I try to create a new mysql connection, I'm prompted to point NetBeans to the JAR, so that it can be used.

The JAR itself was added to the downloads to make unittests possible (https://github.com/apache/netbeans/commit/aec700e82092af3851fd9d8883eadfcd942ee035) and was marked to be `compile-time`:

https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/c73b134cf520288a4ee5101885fb4039253ec496/ide/db.mysql/external/mysql-connector-java-8.0.17-license.txt#L4

Oops. Did not check properly the licensing stuff. 
OK, closing this one, I'd guess - thanks, @matthiasblaesing
Yup, I believe dual licensing (GPL vs. commercial license) was always the core of MySQL business. Looks like the new owner continues to keep it.

Yes, I think it would be preferrable to have the in the 1.8 folder. The folders represent the runtime platform, and are unrelated to the source level supported by the Java parser. (If the selected Java parser does not support the source level, the test will be skipped anyway, but I think we are heading to a place where this won't happen normally.) The spacing around the filename is an interesting design question. In the old Windows and Aqua LAFs, the tabs were designed to take up the absolute minimum amount of vertical space, with just one pixel of spacing from the icon to the top/bottom borders:

![OldSpacing](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/886243/144356158-a99d90e1-8d53-47e2-ae39-3ce45f5a60cb.png)

The current FlatLAF style uses more space, while the proposal in this PR is a bit of a compromise between the two (here showing screenshots with 2x HiDPI/Retina scaling):

![Other LAF Comparisons](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/886243/144356517-db47131f-f0ab-476d-8b92-4d4ee54b687c.png)

In the horizontal direction, the changes in this PR are smaller, mainly to make sure the "X" is closer to the text it is associated with rather than the border before the next tab.

Also the initial commit provides functionality for Debug file. The JPDA debugger is started and execution of the file attach to the JPDA debugger. See more limitation in the issue [NETBEANS-6253](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-6253). The debugger is added only for sharing purposes with Martin Entlicher. If we decide not to add debugger functionality, it can be easily commented out.

Ok - this can't be merged yet, as the unittests for maven fail reproducible (also locallly reproducible!). The issue can be tracked down into a behavioral change in the ModelBuilder implementation of maven. NetBeans overrides a method in the ModelBuilder to enrich the metadata generated. This method was called in 3.6.X from both possible call flows, but is now not called by the default flow anymore. Please have a look at this implementation:

https://github.com/matthiasblaesing/netbeans/commit/b5b45e31e5cc550e0957151ac65cb84a1581fe52

I suggest to get that into this PR and see what the build will do (locally unittests for maven.embedder and maven ran successfully).
@tmysik Thank you for your review! Don't worry. I can wait ;)
